channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Democrats Spent $2 Trillion to Save the Economy. They Don’t Want to Talk About It.
item.description: Polls show voters liked direct payments from President Biden’s 2021 economic rescue bill. But they have become fodder for Republican inflation attacks.
item.dc:creator: Jim Tankersley
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times
item.media:description: A signing ceremony for the American Rescue Plan last year on Capitol Hill. The pandemic aid has largely vanished from stump speeches or campaign ads.

item.title: How Ukraine’s Surrogate Mothers Have Survived the War
item.description: When Russia invaded, Ukraine’s once-booming surrogacy industry seemed at risk of collapsing. But surrogate mothers and agencies have managed to continue deliveries, and clients are arriving again to pick up their children.
item.dc:creator: Maria Varenikova, Andrew E. Kramer and Lynsey Addario
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times

item.title: A shooting at a Russian training camp in the border area kills 11 soldiers, state media reports.
item.dc:creator: James C. McKinley Jr.
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: Billboard of a Russian soldier at a bus stop in Moscow, in August.

item.title: New Generation of Combat Vets, Eyeing House, Strike From the Right
item.description: A class of political newcomers with remarkable military records are challenging old ideas about interventionism — and the assumption that electing veterans is a way to bring back bipartisanship.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Weisman
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Nathan Howard/Getty Images
item.media:description: Joe Kent prays with supporters at a campaign event in Kent, Wash.

item.title: Lake Won’t Pledge to Accept Election Results, and More News From the Sunday Shows
item.description: “I’m going to win the election, and I will accept that result,” Kari Lake, a candidate for governor of Arizona, said on CNN. Evan McMullin said on NBC that he would never caucus with either party.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Astor
item.media:credit: Rebecca Noble for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kari Lake, a candidate for governor of Arizona, in Phoenix. In an interview on CNN, she was asked if she would accept an election loss. “I’m going to win the election, and I will accept that result,” she said.

item.title: China’s Leader Xi Hails His Rule as He Prepares to Expand Power
item.description: Xi Jinping is expected to secure a third term as leader during a pivotal meeting of the Communist Party, extending his authoritarian rule over the country.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley, Keith Bradsher, Vivian Wang and Austin Ramzy
item.media:credit: Mark R Cristino/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping of China on Sunday at the opening ceremony of the 20th National Congress of the Communist Party of China at the Great Hall of the People in Beijing.

item.title: NYC Politicians Say Yes to Big Real Estate Amid Housing Crisis
item.description: Lawmakers on the left are fierce critics of the real estate industry. But some are embracing new housing development, even if it’s not fully affordable.
item.dc:creator: Mihir Zaveri
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: A progressive city councilwoman approved the rezoning of a section of Prospect Heights, which would allow two new residential towers to be built.

item.title: Neymar, Barcelona and the Brazilian Who Still Wants His Money
item.description: A Brazilian supermarket magnate saw promise in the soccer star long before he became a household name. Now, believing he was cheated, he’s going to court for the payday that never arrived.
item.dc:creator: Tariq Panja
item.media:credit: Victor Moriyama for The New York Times
item.media:description: Delcir Sonda, a supermarket magnate, said that after investing millions in Neymar, he didn’t receive any returns.

item.title: As White House Presses for Booster Shots, Americans Are Slow to Get Them
item.description: Only about 15 million doses of the new shots have been administered so far, and many Americans appear to be unaware of or simply uninterested in them.
item.dc:creator: Noah Weiland
item.media:credit: Rosem Morton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rose Jefferson, a nurse supervisor at the Baltimore City Health Department, preparing a coronavirus vaccine this month. Only about 5 percent of Baltimore residents have received one of the new booster shots.

item.title: How to Stay Safe From Covid This Holiday Season
item.description: As our third pandemic winter approaches, you can mitigate risk without missing out.
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum
item.media:credit: Getty Images

item.title: Macron the Disrupter Seeks Direction
item.description: He wants to lead a united Europe to independence. But the world has changed on him.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France at the United Nations General Assembly last month.

item.title: Tens of Thousands March in Paris to Protest Rising Living Costs
item.description: The demonstration occurred on the heels of strikes at oil refineries, adding to a tense political atmosphere.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Julien De Rosa/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Protesters in Paris on Sunday.

item.title: A Posthumous Memoir Reveals Paul Newman in His Own Words
item.description: Compiled from interviews he gave to a close friend, “The Extraordinary Life of an Ordinary Man” sheds light on the self-doubt of the seemingly imperturbable Hollywood star.
item.dc:creator: Dave Itzkoff
item.category: The Extraordinary Life of an Ordinary Man: A Memoir (Book)
item.media:credit: George Rinhart/Corbis via Getty Images
item.media:description: “I am certain that nobody can always be responsible for what other people are,” Paul Newman says in a posthumous memoir surprising for its candor and vulnerability. “You can only be responsible for who you are.”

item.title: Sex, Death, Family: Sharon Olds Is Still Shockingly Intimate
item.description: “No one should read more than one poem at a time from this book.”
item.dc:creator: Sam Anderson
item.media:credit: Ruven Afanador for The New York Times

item.title: Why Herschel Walker May Win
item.description: His performance in the Georgia Senate debate on Friday is a warning to Democrats who’ve found hope in the blunders of Republican candidates.
item.dc:creator: Frank Bruni
item.media:credit: Kendrick Brinson for The New York Times

item.title: We Should Try to Prevent Another Alex Jones
item.description: Even a billion-dollar verdict won’t stop the lies.
item.dc:creator: Zeynep Tufekci
item.media:credit: Kirsten Luce for The New York Times
item.media:description: Alex Jones outside the courthouse in Waterbury, Conn., in September.

item.title: Wait, Who Did You Say Is Middle-Aged?
item.description: Boomers didn’t appreciate getting long in the tooth. But as a Gen Xer, I have to assume it’s worse for us.
item.dc:creator: Pamela Paul

item.title: The Contradictions of Climate Activism
item.description: The energy crisis exposes the cracks in a low-carbon vision.
item.dc:creator: Ross Douthat
item.media:credit: Henry Nicholls/Reuters
item.media:description: A Just Stop Oil protester in London last week.

item.title: How to Fight Back Against the Inhumanity of Modern Work
item.description: Digital technology has transformed work, often for the worse. Here are some solutions.
item.dc:creator: Tish Harrison Warren
item.media:credit: Matija Medved

item.title: Three Things Americans Should Learn From Xi’s China
item.description: The tactics he has used to maintain power may end up weakening his country in the end.
item.dc:creator: Farah Stockman
item.media:credit: Greg Baker/AFP via Getty Images

item.title: Herschel Walker, Butcher of Language
item.description: The Republican Senate candidate is devastatingly inarticulate.
item.dc:creator: Charles M. Blow
item.media:credit: Kendrick Brinson for The New York Times

item.title: Same-Sex Marriage Is a Religious Freedom
item.description: If the law allows same-sex couples to be treated differently from other couples, then our religious freedom to be married is not complete.
item.dc:creator: Steven Paulikas
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.media:credit: Bryan Thomas for The New York Times

item.title: Ketanji Brown Jackson’s Debut
item.description: She has spoken more extensively than other newcomers to the Supreme Court have.
item.dc:creator: Ian Prasad Philbrick
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times
item.media:description: Justice Ketanji Brown Jackson

item.title: The Sunday Read: ‘Daring to Speak Up About Race in a Divided School District’
item.description: What happened when a superintendent in northern Michigan raised the issue of systemic racism?
item.dc:creator: Daniel Bergner, Adrienne Hurst, Aaron Esposito, John Woo, Sophia Lanman and Devin Murphy
item.media:credit: Holly Andres for The New York Times
item.media:description: Stephanie Long, the school superintendent of Leland, Mich., in August.

item.title: The Young Women Who Make TikTok Weep
item.description: Songwriters who have found success on the app via emotional catharsis have expanded its range, and piqued the music industry’s interest.
item.media:credit: Jaime Molina for The New York Times

item.title: 🍄 It’s Mushroom Week! 🍄
item.description: A big batch of mushroom ragout means many delicious meals ahead.
item.dc:creator: Tejal Rao
item.media:credit: Beatriz Da Costa for The New York Times. Food Stylist: Rebecca Jurkevich.

item.title: Elections Approaching, Erdogan Raises the Heat Again With Greece
item.description: Turkey’s president suggested that troops “may suddenly arrive one night” in Greece. With inflation rampant and the lira sinking, a manufactured crisis might be just the thing he needs.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Adem Altan/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey, center, during celebrations in Ankara in August to mark the 100th anniversary of Turkey’s victory against the Greeks in 1922.

item.title: After Weeks of Turmoil, UK Markets Face Another Test on Monday
item.description: Investors will get to weigh in after the Bank of England ended its bond market intervention and the bank’s governor offered conciliatory words over the weekend.
item.dc:creator: Eshe Nelson
item.media:credit: Henry Nicholls/Reuters
item.media:description: Jeremy Hunt, Britain’s new top finance official, sought over the weekend to reassure markets, the public and fellow members of the Conservative Party that he can restore the government’s fiscal credibility

item.title: Secrets Preserved in the Skin of Dakota the ‘Dino Mummy’
item.description: Study of the hadrosaur found a new explanation for how dinosaurs could be mummified with their skin preserved through the eons.
item.dc:creator: Jeanne Timmons

item.title: Astros Eliminate Mariners and Advance to ALCS
item.description: “I feel like this is just the beginning for all of us,” Julio Rodríguez said after the Mariners made the playoffs for the first time since 2001 but were swept by Houston.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Kepner
item.media:credit: Lindsey Wasson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Seattle’s Julio Rodríguez did all he could, but in the 18th inning of Saturday’s epic game with the Houston Astros, he grounded out to end the game.

item.title: 4 Ways to Boost Your Immune System Ahead of Cold and Flu Season
item.description: Here are four things immunologists and other health experts say you can do.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Seo
item.media:credit: Cristina Spanò

item.title: Is Matcha Good for You?
item.description: The brightly colored powdered green tea has become popular among health-conscious consumers. Does it have any nutritional benefits?
item.dc:creator: Annie Sneed
item.media:credit: Eric Helgas for The New York Times

item.title: 6 Ways to Level Up Your Daily Walk
item.description: Experts say Americans are taking more walks than before the pandemic. Here are some ways to turn your neighborhood stroll in to an exciting workout.
item.dc:creator: Emily Pennington
item.media:credit: Yana Paskova for The New York Times

item.title: Vuity Review: I Swapped My Reading Glasses for Magical Eyedrops
item.description: Vuity, taken daily, promises clear vision for up to 10 hours. But does it work?
item.dc:creator: Elisabeth Egan
item.media:credit: Desmond Picotte for The New York Times
item.media:description: Vuity, eyedrops that can help people see up close without affecting their long-range vision, went on the market in December.

item.title: ‘Still Growing Together,’ a Teenage Crush Leads to Marriage
item.description: Brittney Adu was smitten when she saw Aaron Canales on the first day of their freshman year of high school. Despite their cultural differences and the trials of a young romance, their love endured.
item.dc:creator: Tammy La Gorce
item.media:credit: Whitten Sabbatini for The New York Times
item.media:description: Brittney Adu said she felt like the “president of the entire world” when Aaron Canales asked her to be his girlfriend in 2013. The couple married Sept. 17 at the Lichterman Nature Center in Memphis.

item.title: How to Solve Hard Crosswords
item.description: Friday, Saturday and Sunday bring some of the hardest puzzles of the week.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Frere and Isaac Aronow
item.media:credit: Thomas Merceron
